urn:contentItem:6GGN-2J83-RWJ1-0499-00000-00WEEKLY RECAP: DIRECT RELIEF FOUNDATION NEWS THIS PAST WEEK AUG 12, 20252025-08-13T00:00:00Z2025-08-20T19:20:52ZLexisNexisWEEKLY RECAP: DIRECT RELIEF FOUNDATION NEWS THIS PAST WEEK AUG 12, 2025

+ DIRECT RELIEF FOUNDATION [7 Press Releases]

+ TWENTY YEARS AGO, HURRICANE KATRINA TRANSFORMED AMERICAN HEALTHCARE - AND DIRECT RELIEF

When Janet Mentesane thinks back to the sheer scale of medical need after Hurricane Katrina, her strongest memory isn't of providers treating physical trauma or water-borne diseases. It's of people with diabetes, hypertension, and other chronic health issues - the non-communicable diseases that affect billions of people worldwide - evacuating without their medications.

"There was a massive amount of people who were showing up and multiple shelters that were opening up," recalled Mentesane, who was the executive director of MLK Health, a free clinic and pharmacy in Shreveport, Louisiana, about five hours' drive from New Orleans. (She is currently the clinic's grants manager.) "They had no medications and no physicians. Their pharmacies were destroyed, along with the records and data."

Mentesane's experience reflects a larger challenge of the Hurricane Katrina response that surprised many - although not the safety net providers working on the ground.

Source: Company Website

+ DIRECT RELIEF MOBILIZES AID FOR THE CANYON FIRE IN VENTURA AND LOS ANGELES COUNTIES

Direct Relief is responding to two wildfires in California-supporting communities under evacuation from the rapidly spreading Canyon Fire in Los Angeles County while continuing to address smoke-related health risks from the massive Gifford Fire on the Central Coast.

The Canyon Fire, which ignited Thursday near Lake Piru, has burned nearly 5,000 acres. Mandatory evacuation orders are in place for roughly 5,000 people and 700 structures, with an additional 11,000 residents and 4,700 structures under evacuation warnings.

Often as a result of being evacuated, displaced individuals experience disruption in essential healthcare, including lack of access to critically needed medications. People living with chronic conditions such as diabetes, asthma, and hypertension may be forced to leave home without the medicines or supplies they rely on daily. Within a 20-mile radius of the Canyon Fire, seven Direct Relief-supported health centers are part of a critical network needed to ensure that displaced and impacted residents can refill prescriptions and receive care during and after the emergency. The organization has contacted each location, offering any medical aid assistance needed.

Source: Company Website

+ DIRECT RELIEF FOUNDATION GIFFORD FIRE RESPONSE: N95 RESPIRATORS AVAILABLE IN SANTA BARBARA COUNTY

In response to the Gifford Fire, Direct Relief is distributing free N95 respirators to people experiencing poor air quality as a result of the fire.

The Gifford Fire, which broke out on August 1 in northern Santa Barbara County, was the largest fire burning in California as of Thursday, when acres burned neared 100,000. The fire is currently about 15 percent contained and is impacting rural areas of San Luis Obispo and Santa Barbara Counties.

Direct Relief is based in Santa Barbara County, and has extensive experience responding to wildfires across the state. This week, the organization provided free respirators to residents at multiple locations throughout the county and will continue to respond as air quality needs continue.

Source: Company Website

+ DIRECT RELIEF FOUNDATION IN CENTRAL TEXAS, A HEALTH CENTER CARES FOR FLOOD-DEVASTATED COMMUNITIES, FIRST RESPONDERS - AND ITS STAFF

In the first weeks after floods tore through central Texas, killing at least 138 people and damaging thousands of homes, people kept their heads down and pushed through.

Mikki Hand, a family nurse practitioner and executive director of Frontera Healthcare, a community health center serving a number of severely impacted communities, described a provider who came into work despite losing her home to the floods. "I have more than our patients, and I didn't lose somebody," the provider told her.

"I can control this, but I can help people. If I go home, I have nothing left, and I'm not ready to deal with that," Hand recalled a staff member saying.

Hand, a seasoned provider and community health leader, knew the worst need was still ahead.

Frontera staff who had lost their homes or suffered severe damage faced overwhelming financial challenges. Meanwhile, first responders-nearly all of them volunteers-were returning to their own hard-hit neighborhoods after taking on swift water rescues and emergency operations that otherwise might not have happened, Hand explained. "They're expected to resume their everyday lives," she said.

Source: Company Website

+ DIRECT RELIEF FOUNDATION BEYOND ABCS: SCHOOL-BASED HEALTH CENTERS PROVIDE CARE FOR STUDENTS

School isn't just a place for students to learn; it's increasingly become a place young people rely on for critical services, including healthcare. That's the case for over 7,000 students in two parishes in northwestern Louisiana. They can receive wellness checks, vaccines, acute care, and behavioral and chronic health support, all without leaving school grounds. More students are expected to have access to medical care this upcoming school year.

For 30 years, children in four Caddo Parish schools could receive medical care at school. Since students have returned to in-school learning following the pandemic, David Raines Community Health Center has increased those efforts to include 21 schools to encourage and support healthy kids in northern Louisiana.

The school-based program expanded into neighboring Bossier Parish to include two more schools during the 2024-2025 school year, and will grow again in Fall 2025 with an additional mobile medical unit. Health center staff say the increased access to care allows families to learn about basic hygiene and health needs, which will improve the community's quality of life and reduce the risk of chronic diseases.

Source: Company Website

+ NASA SPOTLIGHTS DIRECT RELIEF'S USE OF SATELLITE DATA DURING LOS ANGELES FIRES

When wildfires erupted across Southern California in January 2025, Direct Relief turned to satellite data to understand the scale of destruction-and to trusted community health partners to meet urgent medical needs on the ground. A recent feature by NASA's Applied Sciences Program highlights how real-time imagery and damage modeling supported Direct Relief's situational awareness as fires swept through Los Angeles County.

In the days following the Eaton Fire in Altadena, researchers from Direct Relief and partner institutions used radar imagery from the Copernicus Sentinel-1 satellite to assess structural damage. When layered with fire perimeter data and public infrastructure maps, the result was a publicly available interactive model showing likely damage across the region-including near health facilities.

The analysis, developed in collaboration with Oregon State University's Jamon Van Den Hoek, Microsoft's AI for Good, RxResponse, the Bureau of Primary Health Care, and Direct Relief, helped responders quickly understand which areas faced the most severe impacts.

Source: Company Website

+ BD, DIRECT RELIEF, AND NACHC AWARD FOUR U.S.COMMUNITY HEALTH CENTERS FOR INNOVATION IN CARE

With support from the BD Helping Build Healthy Communities Innovations in Care Award, four U.S.community health centers will be able to advance their innovative care models for at-risk patient populations.

Each center is awarded $225,000 to implement pharmacist-led comprehensive medication management programs for patients - many of whom are vulnerable to chronic disease. These initiatives focus on educating and counseling patients through team-based care, while also addressing Social Determinants of Health that impact patient outcomes.

Recipients of the 2025 BD Helping Build Healthy Communities Innovations in Care award are:

Community Health and Social Services Center (Detroit, MI) will broaden its medication management service for individuals with Type 2 diabetes to include screening for peripheral artery disease and peripheral neuropathy. The program utilizes bilingual community health workers to support enhanced patient communication and engagement. Jane Pauley Community Health Center (Indianapolis, IN) will establish a contextualized care coordination model integrating clinical pharmacists and community health workers to address both clinical needs and social determinants, including nutrition insecurity, transportation, housing, and healthcare access. Family Health Matters Community Health Center (Anaheim, CA) will expand Spanish language-concordant CMM services and implement social determinants of health screening through clinical pharmacy visits. The program will address health literacy, access to healthy food, and social support through expanded group visits.

Source: Company Website

urn:contentItem:6GFT-18H3-RS76-B53C-00000-00Updated: August 04, 2025: Thornton Tomasetti, Inc.: Reflecting on Hurricane Katrina: 20 Years Later and other recent news2025-08-09T00:00:00Z2025-08-20T19:20:52ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSUpdated: August 04, 2025: Thornton Tomasetti, Inc.: Reflecting on Hurricane Katrina: 20 Years Later and other recent news

Hurricane Katrina revealed widespread vulnerabilities in infrastructure, design and disaster response systems. Infrastructure Overhaul - Forensic engineering investigations informed major upgrades to flood defenses and critical facilities in New Orleans. Record-Breaking 2005 Season - The record-breaking 2005 hurricane season reshaped how the engineering community approaches resilience and climate adaptation. Forensic Engineering Advancements - Two decades later, lessons from Katrina continue to influence structural assessment, emergency planning and forensic analysis.

INDEX

SECTION 1 PRESS RELEASES: 2025

SECTION 2 OTHER NEWS: 2025

SECTION 1 PRESS RELEASES: 2025

August 07: Thornton Tomasetti, Inc.: Vice President Melissa Hertel Named a Top Women in Maritime Award Winner

Vice President Melissa Hertel has been named a Top Women in Maritime Award winner. Melissa is one of 20 honorees selected by Marine Log magazine for their achievements and contributions in shaping the future of the maritime industry.

A leader in our Forensics practice, Melissa has more than 35 years of experience in naval architecture and marine engineering. Based in the firm's Seattle office, she leads multidisciplinary teams in providing forensic investigation, litigation support, risk loss consulting, repair and retrofit design services to insurance professionals, legal teams, contractors and vessel, seaport and terminal owners. Melissa and the rest of this year's honorees will be celebrated at an awards ceremony on December 2 in New Orleans, which is being held in conjunction with the International WorkBoat Show.

Source: Company Website

July 11: Thornton Tomasetti, Inc.: Electric Vehicles and Parking Design in the Latest Issue of Parking Today

As more electric vehicles take to the road, parking structures must evolve to accommodate them. Thornton Tomasetti Principal Todd Neal writes about safety, accessibility, increased vehicle weight and other challenges impacting facility design in the latest issue of Parking Today.

Key insights include optimizing layouts for EV charging access, upgrading electrical grids for increased demand, balancing spaces for mixed vehicle types and innovative solutions like streetlight chargers. This article offers forward-thinking strategies for parking facility designers navigating the EV revolution.

Source: Company Website

SECTION 2 OTHER NEWS: 2025

July 30: Thornton Tomasetti, Inc.: Wave Impact to Battery Fires: Real-World Applications of Computational Fluid Dynamics at Thornton Tomasetti

Euan Williamson's CFD wave model analyzes water-air interactions to optimize sea wall and pier designs, reducing overtopping and enhancing climate-adaptive coastal defenses. EV Fire Modeling for Safer Urban Structures - Sarah Swales and Paul Williamson simulate fire spread in enclosed parking structures, helping engineers assess material behavior, fire-induced structural response and improve design safety for EV charging hubs and mixed-use buildings. Cross-Practice Innovation Through CFD - The CFD Community of Practice continues to spark ideas that bridge sustainability, digital tools and protective design, advancing solutions for resilient infrastructure, clean mobility and smarter cities.

Source: Company Website

July 28: Thornton Tomasetti, Inc.: 2025 Bridges to Prosperity: Karuruma Trail Bridge Completed

In May of 2025, Thornton Tomasetti made our annual trip abroad to construct a trail bridge with Bridges to Prosperity. Alongside a local team, our firm sent 11 employees to build a 60-meter suspended bridge spanning the Akaruruma River.

Source: Company Website

July 25: Thornton Tomasetti, Inc.: Vice President Hiva Nasiri Shares Insights with Facilitiesnet

Thornton Tomasetti Vice President Hiva Nasiri shares his insights on risk assessment mistakes and is featured as the opening quote in Maura Keller's latest article for Facilitiesnet, "Common Risk Assessment Mistakes Facility Managers Make."

The article emphasizes crucial areas often overlooked, such as neglecting disaster response drills and insufficient testing of backup power systems like generators and microgrids. These are critical steps to ensure facilities are truly prepared for high-impact weather events and other disruptions.

At Thornton Tomasetti, we're committed to helping organizations build resilience and avoid these pitfalls through comprehensive applied science and engineering solutions.

Source: Company Website

July 24: Thornton Tomasetti, Inc.: An Update on RAAC in the UK

Although headline news on Reinforced Autoclaved Aerated Concrete (RAAC) has quietened in recent years, the persistent issues associated with this notorious construction material continue to present a painful legacy from the mid-1900s.

A CROSS UK (Collaborative Reporting on Safer Structures) report issued in June 2025 highlighted widespread RAAC defects concealed behind layers of paint on the soffit of a public library roof. This observation escalated the premises from an "amber" status to a "red-critical" safety risk. It serves as a stark reminder that defective RAAC structures remain deeply embedded in our aging building stock.

Source: Company Website

July 23: Thornton Tomasetti, Inc.: The Role of Forensics and Predictive Failure Analysis in Additive Manufacturing

Forensics and predictive analysis are vital for safe additive manufacturing (AM) adoption in high-stakes industries, addressing risks from new materials and processes. AM vs. Traditional Manufacturing - Unlike predictable traditional methods, AM's simultaneous material and design development creates complex failure modes, requiring deeper understanding. Real-World AM Failures - Stryker's 2020 implant recall and Alquist 3D's Walmart project issues show AM failures can be subtle, like defects or cost overruns, needing better testing. Proactive Risk Mitigation - Early failure analysis and collaboration with experts are crucial to predict risks and ensure AM's reliable, widespread adoption.

Source: Company Website

July 10: Thornton Tomasetti, Inc.: Principal Michael Wesolowsky Talks Venue Acoustics on Moore in the Morning

Concertgoers at Toronto's temporary Rogers Stadium are expressing concerns about the bleacher seats shaking due to crowd movements. On iHeartRadio's Moore in the Morning podcast today, Principal Mike Wesolowsky of Thornton Tomasetti's acoustics engineering group explained how vibrations are natural for venues and, if properly designed, can safely accommodate fans dancing and enjoying the show.

Source: Company Website

July 07: Thornton Tomasetti, Inc.: What England's Building Safety Act Means for Forensic Engineers and Insurers

The BSA, effective June 28, 2022, imposes sweeping new duties on all "Higher- Risk Buildings"-residential structures over six storeys in England. It enforces rigorous accountability across design, construction, management, and occupancy phases. Forensic engineers vital for maintaining safety records - Engineers are now central to maintaining the "Golden Thread" - a complete, traceable safety record - through risk assessments, documentation and investigative techniques to help buildings comply. Insurers face higher liability exposure - With tighter oversight and mandatory safety data, insurers must adjust pricing, underwriting, and risk models.

Source: Company Website

July 01: Thornton Tomasetti, Inc.: Preparing a Construction Site Ahead of a Major Hurricane

All too often, storm preparation is poor on job sites, which can result in major failures. For example, a crane collapsed on a St. Petersburg, Florida, job site during Hurricane Milton in 2024, and, in 2020, 27 construction barges broke away from their moorings and were scattered during Hurricane Sally, some of them colliding with the Pensacola Bay Bridge and causing extensive damage.

Source: Company Website

July 01: Thornton Tomasetti, Inc.: Factory of the Future Tops Out in Maine

Dubbed the Factory of the Future, The University of Maine Green Energy & Materials (GEM) building recently topped out in Orono, Maine. The new, 60,000-square-foot building will serve as a research and education facility focused on advanced manufacturing, expanding the frontiers of large-format and AI-enabled arrays of additive manufacturing systems to create new markets for sustainable building materials.

Source: Company Website

June 26: Thornton Tomasetti, Inc.: Athletics Break Ground on Las Vegas MLB Ballpark

The new A's Las Vegas ballpark has broken ground. The 33,000-seat Major League ballpark, located at the south end of the famed Las Vegas Strip, was designed by BIG - Bjarke Ingels Group and HNTB with structural engineering by Thornton Tomasetti.

The domed stadium's split upper and lower seating bowls provide clear sight lines and bring fans closer to the field. The long-span roof's five overlapping "pennants" are supported on 700-foot span arch trusses, and one of the world's largest cable-net glass facades in the park's outfield will provide expansive views of the Strip.

Source: Company Website

June 25: Thornton Tomasetti, Inc.: Miami Herald: Take a look inside Inter Miamis Miami Freedom Park Stadium

The new 25,000-seat home for soccer team Inter Miami, Miami Freedom Park Stadium is under construction and expected to open in Spring 2026. Featuring a tensile canopy roof, the stadium comprises a two-tier seating bowl with an elevated main concourse, sideline balconies with clubs, suites and a press box. Source: Company Website

June 25: Thornton Tomasetti, Inc.: Miami Herald: Take a look inside Inter Miami's Miami Freedom Park Stadium

The new 25,000-seat home for soccer team Inter Miami, Miami Freedom Park Stadium is under construction and expected to open in Spring 2026. Featuring a tensile canopy roof, the stadium comprises a two-tier seating bowl with an elevated main concourse, sideline balconies with clubs, suites and a press box.

We are providing structural design to Manica for the project, which will boast the largest canopy in the league. The project is being delivered on an extremely aggressive schedule to achieve an accelerated opening date.

Iconic soccer player Lionel Messi, who is expected to extend his contract through 2026, will likely play in the stadium when it opens.

Source: Company Website

June 01: Thornton Tomasetti, Inc.: 2025 Hurricane Season Predictions and How to Prepare Commercial and Residential Properties

Forecasts predict an above-average season with 13-19 named storms, 6-10 hurricanes, and 3-5 major hurricanes, driven by warm Atlantic waters and a La NiNa pattern, increasing risks for coastal areas. Preparation for Commercial Properties - Secure construction sites by anchoring materials, protecting equipment, and reinforcing structures; develop evacuation plans and ensure compliance with local regulations to mitigate damage and ensure safety. Preparation for Residential Properties - Homeowners should inspect roofs, secure outdoor items, elevate appliances above flood levels, and prepare emergency kits with essentials like food, water, and entertainment for potential power outages. Post-Storm Recovery - Conduct thorough inspections for structural damage, clear debris safely and coordinate with professionals to assess and repair properties before resuming operations or reoccupying homes.

Source: Company Website

June 01: Thornton Tomasetti, Inc.: 2025 Hurricane Season Predictions and How to Prepare Commercial and Residential Properties

Hurricane season is upon us once again. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) recently released its predictions, which, as in recent years, have called for above-normal activity in the Atlantic basin for this year.

We'll delve into these predictions and offer some solutions on how best to prepare commercial and residential properties for before, during and after the storm.

Source: Company Website

May 23: Thornton Tomasetti, Inc.: Astra Tower Opens

Not just the tallest building in Utah, the 41-story Astra Tower also boasts distinctive features such as an air quality beacon and the state's largest mural. It officially opened last week in Salt Lake City.

We provided structural design services for the luxury residential building, designed by HKS, Inc. and developed by Kensington Investment Company. Rising more than 450 feet, Astra Tower offers a mix of apartments ranging from studios to three-bedroom units, including two levels of penthouse residences. Because the tower's height exceeds code limits for a single lateral force-resisting system, a performance-based design approach was employed, resulting in a structure engineered to withstand seismic events with a 2,500-year recurrence interval. The building's structure consists of flat plate post-tensioned concrete slabs and cast-in-place concrete columns, with a lateral system of concrete shear walls at the core and egress stairways.

Source: Company Website

May 22: Thornton Tomasetti, Inc. Mahan Named To ENRs National Top 20 Under 40

Congratulations to Associate Jennifer Mahan on being named one of Engineering News-Record's National Top 20 Under 40 for 2025. The award recognizes 20 of the nation's rising construction and design professionals for their contributions to the industry and their communities. Jen, a member of our Sustainability and Resilience practice in New York, was honored for her work mitigating the impact of climate change on the built environment and her commitment to greater inclusivity in the engineering profession.

Source: Company Website

May 22: Thornton Tomasetti, Inc.: Construction Underway On Karuruma Trail Bridge

Partnering with nonprofit Bridges to Prosperity, our 2025 Thornton Tomasetti Gives Back service team has travelled to the Rwanda to complete work on a 60-meter (nearly 200-foot) suspended cable bridge spanning the Akaruruma River. For the villages of Kigusa and Kintama, the river presents a significant obstacle-especially during the rainy season, when flooding can cut off access to schools, health care, markets, and other essential services. Source: Company Website

urn:contentItem:6GD2-H363-RTV1-B29Y-00000-00THE WATCHLIST2025-08-02T00:00:00Z2025-08-20T19:20:52ZLexisNexisREVIEWPg. 10THE WATCHLISTGEORDIE GRAH

Bookish HBO Max If you're after a scrumptious, cosy crime drama where the murders are just the garnish and the true pleasure lies in pottering about dusty old bookshops and cooing over vintage pill bottles, Bookish is the best on the market. Written by and starring Mark Gatiss, it follows Gabriel Book, owner of the cheekily named Book's, a second-hand bookshop in post-war London. He's the very model of a jolly-good bookseller, charming and arch, with a tome for everything. But he's also a nosy parker and recreational sleuth. Book carries a "letter from Churchill" in his breast pocket, which hints at covert wartime gallantry but, crucially, gives him carte blanche to insert himself into any investigation that tickles his fancy. Each mystery is spread over two episodes, but the real joy isn't in solving anything - it's in hanging out with the characters. Polly Walker is a delight as Book's wife, Trottie, and their backstory (which I won't spoil) adds a moving layer to all the detective work. Warm, whimsical and stuffed with cracking wallpaper, these six episodes are the perfect wintry binge.

Chief of War Apple TV+ from Friday If you're still searching for your next big epic history drama post-Shogun, this'll do nicely. Jason Momoa, never less than mythically jacked, stars as Ka'iana, a shark-wrangling warrior drawn back into battle amid a looming war to unify the Hawaiian islands. Set in the late 1700s, when the islands were fractured into rival chiefdoms and Western influence loomed, the series follows the rise of King Kamehameha (a stately Kaina Makua), who dreams of uniting Hawaii, Maui, O'ahu and Kaua'i under one rule. This is a passion project from Momoa and co-creator Thomas Pa'a Sibbett, both of Native Hawaiian descent, told from an indigenous perspective with dialogue in the Polynesian language. Expect bloodcurdling battles, snazzy spearwork, and towering performances from New Zealand's finest: Temuera Morrison and Cliff Curtis.

Wednesday Season 2 premieres on Netflix, August 8 The ookiest, spookiest Netflix hit Wednesday returns next week, with four episodes in part one. If you skipped the first season on the grounds it was "for kids", I implore you to reconsider. This Addams Family riff is the best thing Tim Burton's made in yonks. Heavy is the head that wears Christina Ricci's goth girl crown, but Jenna Ortega more than earned her keep as the exquisitely affectless Wednesday. This season, we're back at Nevermore Academy with a new headmaster: the suspiciously wholesome Barry Dort, played by Steve Buscemi, whose very casting screams "definitely hiding something". Also crashing the crypt: Joanna Lumley as Morticia's mother and Billie Piper. And yes, Lady Gaga is coming - but you'll have to wait until Part Two drops in September for that particular seance.

Landscapers Stan The internet's current boyfriend is, without a doubt, Will Sharpe - thanks to his lethally charismatic turn in Lena Dunham's Too Much. But did you know he's also a director? And not just any director, but a properly odd, properly brilliant one. Landscapers, his 2021 true-crime drama series, stars David Thewlis and Olivia Colman (if that casting alone doesn't convince you, what will?) as Susan and Christopher Edwards, an awkward, soft-spoken couple with a shared love of Westerns, old Hollywood and Gerard Depardieu. They are also murderers. In 1998, the couple shot Susan's elderly parents and buried them in their suburban Mansfield back garden - a crime that went unnoticed for over a decade. It sounds like typical true-crime dross, but in Sharpe's hands, it isn't. He steers it gleefully off-road; what emerges is less a whodunit and more a portrait of two people who built a fantasy world held together by love, denial and VHS tapes. Colman is extraordinary (obviously), and Thewlis matches her beat for beat. A true-crime drama that refuses to play by the genre's rules - weird, elegant, and unlike anything else on TV. I've been thinking about it for years.

Hurricane Katrina: Race Against Time Netflix Two decades after Hurricane Katrina devastated New Orleans, this deeply upsetting five-part documentary revisits the disaster and the man-made failures that turned it into a national disgrace. Told through the eyes of survivors, organisers and officials, it lays out how environmental negligence, systemic racism and political inertia collided to produce something far worse than a natural catastrophe. There are wrenching testimonies and shocking footage, with an undercurrent of fury and sorrow. Created by Traci A. Curry, this is a measured, dignified piece of filmmaking - a human-centred account of a government that failed its citizens. Essential viewing.

urn:contentItem:6GGM-RGX3-RY6T-Y06M-00000-00Updated: August 11, 2025: Twenty Years Ago, Hurricane Katrina Transformed American Healthcare - and Direct Relief and other recent news2025-08-13T00:00:00Z2025-08-20T19:20:53ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSUpdated: August 11, 2025: Twenty Years Ago, Hurricane Katrina Transformed American Healthcare - and Direct Relief and other recent news

When Janet Mentesane thinks back to the sheer scale of medical need after Hurricane Katrina, her strongest memory isn't of providers treating physical trauma or water-borne diseases. It's of people with diabetes, hypertension, and other chronic health issues - the non-communicable diseases that affect billions of people worldwide - evacuating without their medications.

"There was a massive amount of people who were showing up and multiple shelters that were opening up," recalled Mentesane, who was the executive director of MLK Health, a free clinic and pharmacy in Shreveport, Louisiana, about five hours' drive from New Orleans. (She is currently the clinic's grants manager.) "They had no medications and no physicians.Their pharmacies were destroyed, along with the records and data."

Mentesane's experience reflects a larger challenge of the Hurricane Katrina response that surprised many - although not the safety net providers working on the ground.

August 05: BD, Direct Relief, and NACHC Award Four U.S. Community Health Centers for Innovation in Care

With support from the BD Helping Build Healthy Communities Innovations in Care Award, four U.S.community health centers will be able to advance their innovative care models for at-risk patient populations.

Each center is awarded $225,000 to implement pharmacist-led comprehensive medication management programs for patients - many of whom are vulnerable to chronic disease. These initiatives focus on educating and counseling patients through team-based care, while also addressing Social Determinants of Health that impact patient outcomes.

Recipients of the 2025 BD Helping Build Healthy Communities Innovations in Care award are:

Community Health and Social Services Center (Detroit, MI) will broaden its medication management service for individuals with Type 2 diabetes to include screening for peripheral artery disease and peripheral neuropathy. The program utilizes bilingual community health workers to support enhanced patient communication and engagement. Jane Pauley Community Health Center (Indianapolis, IN) will establish a contextualized care coordination model integrating clinical pharmacists and community health workers to address both clinical needs and social determinants, including nutrition insecurity, transportation, housing, and healthcare access. Family Health Matters Community Health Center (Anaheim, CA) will expand Spanish language-concordant CMM services and implement social determinants of health screening through clinical pharmacy visits. The program will address health literacy, access to healthy food, and social support through expanded group visits.

Source: Company Website

July 30: Direct Relief Awards $250,000 to Texas Organizations Responding to Catastrophic Flooding

In the wake of severe and widespread flooding across Texas Hill Country in early July, Direct Relief has awarded $250,000 in emergency grant funding to five local organizations delivering critical services to impacted communities. The grants support frontline search-and-rescue and recovery efforts, mental health services, and healthcare access for displaced residents, first responders, and health workers directly affected by the floods.

TEXSAR (Texas Search and Rescue) - $50,000 to support volunteer-based flood and swiftwater rescue operations, including equipment and training needs. Texas EquuSearch - $50,000 to offset volunteer lodging and deployment costs during ongoing search and recovery missions. Center Point Volunteer Fire Department - $50,000 to support the purchase of a swiftwater rescue boat and to replace other supplies and equipment lost due to the fire station flooding. La Esperanza Clinic - $50,000 to expand mobile medical outreach and public health efforts for flood-affected communities in San Angelo and the Concho Valley. Frontera Healthcare Network - $50,000 to cover healthcare costs for flood survivors, provide mental health and other wraparound services to first responders, and give emergency cash assistance to health center staff experiencing serious financial impacts, enabling them to continue their work.

Source: Company Website

SECTION 3 OTHER NEWS: 2025

August 08: Direct Relief Mobilizes Aid for the Canyon Fire in Ventura and Los Angeles Counties

Direct Relief is responding to two wildfires in California-supporting communities under evacuation from the rapidly spreading Canyon Fire in Los Angeles County while continuing to address smoke-related health risks from the massive Gifford Fire on the Central Coast.

The Canyon Fire, which ignited Thursday near Lake Piru, has burned nearly 5,000 acres. Mandatory evacuation orders are in place for roughly 5,000 people and 700 structures, with an additional 11,000 residents and 4,700 structures under evacuation warnings.

Often as a result of being evacuated, displaced individuals experience disruption in essential healthcare, including lack of access to critically needed medications. People living with chronic conditions such as diabetes, asthma, and hypertension may be forced to leave home without the medicines or supplies they rely on daily. Within a 20-mile radius of the Canyon Fire, seven Direct Relief-supported health centers are part of a critical network needed to ensure that displaced and impacted residents can refill prescriptions and receive care during and after the emergency. The organization has contacted each location, offering any medical aid assistance needed.

Source: Company Website

August 07: Direct Relief Foundation Gifford Fire Response: N95 Respirators Available in Santa Barbara County

In response to the Gifford Fire, Direct Relief is distributing free N95 respirators to people experiencing poor air quality as a result of the fire.

The Gifford Fire, which broke out on August 1 in northern Santa Barbara County, was the largest fire burning in California as of Thursday, when acres burned neared 100,000. The fire is currently about 15 percent contained and is impacting rural areas of San Luis Obispo and Santa Barbara Counties.

Direct Relief is based in Santa Barbara County, and has extensive experience responding to wildfires across the state. This week, the organization provided free respirators to residents at multiple locations throughout the county and will continue to respond as air quality needs continue.

Source: Company Website

August 07: Direct Relief Foundation In Central Texas, A Health Center Cares for Flood-Devastated Communities, First Responders - and Its Staff

In the first weeks after floods tore through central Texas, killing at least 138 people and damaging thousands of homes, people kept their heads down and pushed through.

Mikki Hand, a family nurse practitioner and executive director of Frontera Healthcare, a community health center serving a number of severely impacted communities, described a provider who came into work despite losing her home to the floods. "I have more than our patients, and I didn't lose somebody," the provider told her.

"I can control this, but I can help people. If I go home, I have nothing left, and I'm not ready to deal with that," Hand recalled a staff member saying.

Hand, a seasoned provider and community health leader, knew the worst need was still ahead.

Frontera staff who had lost their homes or suffered severe damage faced overwhelming financial challenges. Meanwhile, first responders-nearly all of them volunteers-were returning to their own hard-hit neighborhoods after taking on swift water rescues and emergency operations that otherwise might not have happened, Hand explained. "They're expected to resume their everyday lives," she said.

Source: Company Website

August 06: Direct Relief Foundation Beyond ABCs: School-Based Health Centers Provide Care for Students

School isn't just a place for students to learn; it's increasingly become a place young people rely on for critical services, including healthcare. That's the case for over 7,000 students in two parishes in northwestern Louisiana. They can receive wellness checks, vaccines, acute care, and behavioral and chronic health support, all without leaving school grounds. More students are expected to have access to medical care this upcoming school year.

For 30 years, children in four Caddo Parish schools could receive medical care at school. Since students have returned to in-school learning following the pandemic, David Raines Community Health Center has increased those efforts to include 21 schools to encourage and support healthy kids in northern Louisiana.

The school-based program expanded into neighboring Bossier Parish to include two more schools during the 2024-2025 school year, and will grow again in Fall 2025 with an additional mobile medical unit. Health center staff say the increased access to care allows families to learn about basic hygiene and health needs, which will improve the community's quality of life and reduce the risk of chronic diseases.

Source: Company Website

August 05: NASA Spotlights Direct Relief's Use of Satellite Data During Los Angeles Fires

When wildfires erupted across Southern California in January 2025, Direct Relief turned to satellite data to understand the scale of destruction-and to trusted community health partners to meet urgent medical needs on the ground. A recent feature by NASA's Applied Sciences Program highlights how real-time imagery and damage modeling supported Direct Relief's situational awareness as fires swept through Los Angeles County.

In the days following the Eaton Fire in Altadena, researchers from Direct Relief and partner institutions used radar imagery from the Copernicus Sentinel-1 satellite to assess structural damage. When layered with fire perimeter data and public infrastructure maps, the result was a publicly available interactive model showing likely damage across the region-including near health facilities.

The analysis, developed in collaboration with Oregon State University's Jamon Van Den Hoek, Microsoft's AI for Good, RxResponse, the Bureau of Primary Health Care, and Direct Relief, helped responders quickly understand which areas faced the most severe impacts.

Source: Company Website

August 04: Direct Relief Foundation For Children in Ukraine, Medical Transport Covers Last Mile to Care

When war broke out in February 2022, German paramedic Marc Friedrich was in disbelief.

"We had imagined that there would be no more war in Europe, and then suddenly Russia attacked," he recalled.

That disbelief soon gave way to determination.

On March 9, an airstrike struck Mariupol's Maternity Hospital No. 3, killing four people and injuring at least 16 others.

"That was a trigger moment for me," said Friedrich, who left his role as emergency services paramedic chief near Dusseldorf to establish a dedicated ambulance service for children in Ukraine.

"I wanted to configure an ambulance specially to the needs of children, where the equipment doesn't have to be specially prepared for them but is rather the standard," said Friedrich, founder of Ambulance for Kids. Such emergency service vehicles are very rare in both Germany and Ukraine, Friedrich notes.

Acquiring an ambulance and equipping it for pediatric care cost at least $350,000. With support from a range of partners, the NGO began operating on the ground in July 2023. Direct Relief joined in 2025 with a grant to help sustain operations.

The final touch was the interior decor. "We conducted an action in Western Ukraine with a local artist to get the inside painted by children for children, so that it looks beautiful for patients, not just white," said Friedrich.

August 01: Direct Relief FoundationMedical Aid for Myanmar, 18 Other Countries, Departs This Week

Over the past week, Direct Relief has delivered 580 shipments of requested medical aid to 47 U.S. states and territories and 19 countries worldwide. The shipments contained 6.3 million defined daily doses of medication.

Medications and supplies shipped this week include rare disease therapies, diabetes management medications, pharmaceutical-grade refrigeration units, surgical supplies, field medic packs for first responders, and more.

Source: Company Website

July 31: Direct Relief FoundationEquipping Midwives for Success and Transforming Maternal Health in Nigeria

Dr. Faith Adole, founder of the U-VOL Foundation, is revolutionizing maternal and neonatal healthcare in rural Nigeria through the Value Her initiative. The program, born from a stark reality check-a shocking 51 percent maternal mortality rate at a rural Nigerian hospital in 2023-aims to empower local midwives and other health workers with critical education and essential supplies.

Adole's vision is deeply rooted in the belief that sustainable change comes from within communities and is championed by those who best understand their unique needs.

"About 85 percent of the people who attended our programs were women and children," she said. "But in 2023, we heard an alarming statistic: the maternal mortality rate at a rural hospital in Nigeria was 51 percent. That changed everything."

Adole, a nurse and a Black woman, established the U-VOL Foundation in 2014. The organization's mission focuses on creating high-quality, community-driven programs while challenging the scarcity of diverse leadership in global health. Her decision to focus initially on Nigeria stemmed from personal connections and a firsthand understanding of the immense need. The Value Her initiative was a direct response to the candid feedback from midwives and other health staff themselves, who articulated a pressing need not for complex solutions, but for fundamental education and basic supplies.

July 29: Direct Relief Foundation Emergency Update: Direct Relief Monitoring Tsunami Threats in Pacific

Direct Relief is closely monitoring reports of an 8.8-magnitude earthquake off the coast of Russia and the resulting tsunami warnings, which have prompted evacuation orders across Japan and Hawaiʻ i, as well as other coastal areas throughout the Pacific Ocean.

Direct Relief is coordinating with the organization's network of healthcare providers, first responder organizations, and international agencies across at-risk areas to assess needs and stands ready to provide emergency medical support and supplies should needs arise. In the United States, Direct Relief is in communication with the Hawaiʻ i Primary Care Association and the Hawaiʻ i Department of Health to assess potential medical needs and ensure readiness to support affected communities. Direct Relief is also in communication with the Northwest Regional Primary Care Association, which includes Alaska health centers.

In Japan, the organization is coordinating with Peace Winds Japan, a non-governmental disaster response organization, to evaluate needs on the ground and offer emergency medical supplies and support.

In the South Pacific, Direct Relief is coordinating with the Pacific Community, formerly the South Pacific Commission, as well as the Pacific Island Health Officers Association.

July 29: Direct Relief Foundation The Hidden Part Of Wildfire Recovery in Altadena, And Beyond

Seven months after the Eaton Fire tore through Altadena, many families are still living in temporary housing, schools are adjusting to the loss of students, and residents are grappling with more than the logistics of rebuilding their homes. For many, the emotional debris of the disaster lingers on.

"Most people will get to the other side of this," said Sheila Thornton, Clinical Director at Foothill Family, a nonprofit mental health organization serving the San Gabriel Valley. "But you don't forget it. You'll take pieces of it that you keep with you always."

Thornton, who joined Foothill Family in 1985 as a contract social worker, responded to her first major after the October 1993 Altadena wildfires. Three months later, Los Angeles was hit by the 6.7-magnitude Northridge earthquake, which killed at least 57 people.

In the aftermath, Foothill Family received a FEMA grant to study the mental health impact of those events and developed expertise in trauma long before trauma-informed care became common practice.

"Experiencing a traumatic event impacts you physically, emotionally, behaviorally, and cognitively," Thornton said. "You can't sleep, you snap at people, you can't focus or make decisions."

July 28: Direct Relief Foundation The Solidarity Foundation of the Divine Child Jesus and Direct Relief Inaugurate a Modern Solidarity Collection Center in Santiago de los Caballeros

Fundacion Solidaria del Divino NiNo Jesus, Inc. and Direct Relief, a leading global humanitarian organization in emergency medical assistance, celebrated the inauguration and blessing of the Divino NiNo Solidarity Collection Center, a state-of-the-art logistics facility that will optimize the distribution of medicines, medical equipment, and health supplies to vulnerable communities throughout the region.

The new center, which has three levels, will serve as a fundamental logistical hub to strengthen the social and charitable actions of both the Foundation and the Archdiocese of Santiago de los Caballeros. From this space, donations of medicines, medical equipment, emergency kits, expendable materials and other essential supplies that will impact thousands of people will be channeled through institutions such as the National Health Service in the Cibao Norte region, religious communities, hospices, Caritas and social pastoral programs. The infrastructure includes specialized areas for temperature-controlled storage of medicines, refrigerated rooms, administrative offices and modern logistics spaces designed to optimize the reception, organization and distribution of donations.

Source: Company Website

July 28: Direct Relief Foundation A New Medical Logistics Center Will Increase Access to Treatment Across the Dominican Republic

Fundacion Solidaria del Divino NiNo Jesus, Inc. and Direct Relief celebrated the inauguration of a new medical logistics center in the Dominican Republic on Saturday, July 26.

Divino NiNo Solidarity Collection Center, located in the city of Santiago de los Caballeros, will optimize the distribution of medicines, medical equipment, and supplies for vulnerable communities throughout the region. With efficient access to both rural and urban communities, the center will increase medical capacity and transport, reducing the hurdles that prevent access to treatment.

From this space, donations of medicines, medical equipment, emergency kits, consumable materials and other essential supplies will be channeled to impact thousands of people through institutions such as the National Health Service in the North Cibao region, religious communities, hospices, and charitable programs.

Three stories of medical infrastructure include specialized areas for storing medicines at precise temperatures, rooms outfitted for cold-chain storage and staging, administrative offices, and logistics spaces designed to optimize the reception, organization, and distribution of donations. 

Source: Company Website

July 25: Direct Relief Foundation Supporting First Responder Community Health Centers, Mobile Health, and More

Over the past week, Direct Relief has delivered 328 shipments of requested medical aid to 44 U.S. states and territories and 17 countries worldwide. The shipments contained 4.7 million defined daily doses of medication.

Medications and supplies shipped this week include rare disease therapies, diabetes management medications, pharmaceutical-grade refrigeration units, surgical supplies, field medic packs for first responders, and more.

From Response to Recovery, AltaMed Steps Up for Patients Wildfire recovery is ongoing across communities in Los Angeles impacted by the Jan. 2025 blazes. Direct Relief supported local organizations providing patient care, including local health AltaMed, which quickly swung into action to provide medical care to evacuees inside the Pasadena Convention Center, as well as to patients in the community.

Source: Company Website

July 24: Direct Relief Foundation After Hurricane Helene and Amid Increased Need, Free Clinic in Western North Carolina Opens Medical Hub

During a visit earlier this year, the new 16,000-square-foot location of Vecinos Community Health Hub was buzzing with life.

"You can hear the excitement in the hallways," said Marianne Martinez, CEO of Vecinos, a free and charitable clinic serving patients in western North Carolina. "The staff and patients are happy to have this space."

Martinez, who has been with the organization since 2017, gave Direct Relief staff a tour of the health hub and said the $8 million building allows the free and charitable clinic to better serve patients, who are low-income, uninsured, adults in western North Carolina with a specific focus on the Latinx and agricultural worker communities.

The organization has adapted throughout the years to meet the needs of patients since its founding in 2001 through the Jackson County Public Health Department. Within three years, it was operating as a nonprofit mobile medical clinic for farmworkers across western North Carolina. In 2020, the Vecinos community began to think strategically about the future of the health hub from patient feedback that demonstrated a need for more bilingual free clinic services.

Source:Company Website

July 23: Direct Relief Foundation Across a Vast Terrain, Rural Health Centers Fill Crucial Gaps

People who live in the sparsely northernmost areas of Minnesota often travel to a Scenic Rivers facility when they need healthcare. "A lot of people live on the lakes. They're not in our community but we take care of them," Harvey said. "We are the primary caregiver to that whole region up there."

"It's very high touch: Our volumes are low, but our needs are high," said Kate Surbaugh, CEO of Sawtooth Mountain Clinic, a health center in northeastern Minnesota. New staff members often develop a "deer-in-the-headlights look" when they realize how complicated patient care in the area is.

Source: Company Website

July 22: Direct Relief Foundation From Palisades to Eaton: How Safety-Net Clinics Adapted to L.A.'s Dual Wildfires

When wildfires exploded on the west and east sides of Los Angeles County at the start of this year, the Palisades Fire near Malibu and the Eaton Fire in the foothills of the San Gabriel Valley, safety-net clinics and mobile health care providers faced differing realities. Though united in their mission to serve vulnerable patients, providers in the Palisades, Altadena, and the surrounding area, and other parts of L.A. navigated the blazes with distinct challenges, from evacuation orders to air quality crises. Supported by Direct Relief, which delivered rapid aid to clinics in both zones, these community health workers offer a revealing look at how fire response varies across the county's geographic and socioeconomic divides.

Direct Relief spoke with health care providers and leaders at Medical Mission Adventures, Arroyo Vista Family Health Center, and Universal Community Health Centers, who shared their experiences and perspectives since the wildfires began.

Source: Company Website

July 17: Direct Relief Foundation Responding to Texas Floods, Medical Needs in Rural Puerto Rico, and More

Direct Relief staff have been traveling through Kerr County and other flood-impacted parts of central Texas this week to support first responders and health facilities. Flooding earlier this month killed at least 135 people and more than 100 people remain unaccounted for as recovery efforts continue.

Direct Relief has been supporting search and rescue groups, including TEXSAR and Equusearch, with emergency operating grants as well as field medic packs to equip responders with first aid essentials for triage care. Direct Relief staff met with both groups this week to discuss supporting ongoing needs and also met with the Center Point Volunteer Fire Department, where Direct Relief delivered field medic packs that will be integrated into the fire department's response vehicles.

Direct Relief staff also met with health organizations responding to flooded communities, including Fronteras Health Center, which has been providing mental health services to first responders. Direct Relief also met with La Esperanza Clinic in San Angelo, Texas, which has been providing mobile healthcare to the community.

Source: Company Website

AUSTIN

Series return | 4 Stars Rating

Sunday, 7.30pm, ABC

The heartwarming and hilarious Australian-British comedy returns with neurodiverse Austin (Michael Theo, Love on the Spectrum) on the verge of finding out the DNA results as to whether disgraced children's author Julian (Ben Miller, Death In Paradise) is actually his father. It's not the only relationship on a precipice with Ingrid (Sally Phillips, the Bridget Jones movies) reevaluating her connection with Julian going so far as to keep tabs on his pros and cons via notebook tally.

GORDON RAMSAY'S

SECRET SERVICE

New series | 3.5 Stars Rating

Wednesday, 7.30pm, Ten

The potty-mouthed celeb chef returns in his latest, a Kitchen Nightmares-style scenario where Ramsay helps struggling restaurants with his usual tough love approach. However, the action is spiced up by Ramsay living out his undercover agent fantasies sending in secret diners and watching the action from a surveillance van. The first episode follows a once thriving Greek restaurant which is now suffering as patriarch Pete is unwilling to pass over control of the kitchen to his son.

HURRICANE KATRINA:

RACE AGAINST TIME

Docuseries | 4 Stars Rating

Streaming from Monday, Disney+

Ahead of the 20th anniversary of the devastating natural disaster, this gripping five-part National Geographic documentary makes one feel right alongside the abject terror with archival footage and the voices of survivors themselves. It's skilfully shown how human decisions and errors compounded the event into becoming a

man-made tragedy that truly struck the city and residents of New Orleans, with one interviewee calling it "a hurricane of governmental failure".

MARC MARON: PANICKED

Comedy special | 4 Stars Rating

Streaming from Saturday, HBO Max

With Stephen Colbert's recent axing from his late-night show seat, many suspecting for politically motivated reasons, it feels more important than ever for comedians to keep speaking out. Maron's latest stand-up special opens with a blistering and riotously funny spray against Trump, or as he describes him, "this sociopathic huckster clown king", his supporters and policies. The 70-minute set also delves into Maron's intrusive catastrophic thinking and the cognitive decline of his father, both of which he makes sound much funnier than one would believe possible.

Series return | 4 Stars Rating

Sunday, 7.30pm, ABC

The heartwarming and hilarious Australian-British comedy returns with neurodiverse Austin (Michael Theo, Love on the Spectrum) on the verge of finding out the DNA results as to whether disgraced children's author Julian (Ben Miller, Death In Paradise) is actually his father. It's not the only relationship on a precipice with Ingrid (Sally Phillips, the Bridget Jones movies) reevaluating her connection with Julian going so far as to keep tabs on his pros and cons via notebook tally.

GORDON RAMSAY'S

SECRET SERVICE

New series | 3.5 Stars Rating

Wednesday, 7.30pm, Ten

The potty-mouthed celeb chef returns in his latest, a Kitchen Nightmares-style scenario where Ramsay helps struggling restaurants with his usual tough love approach. However, the action is spiced up by Ramsay living out his undercover agent fantasies sending in secret diners and watching the action from a surveillance van. The first episode follows a once thriving Greek restaurant which is now suffering as patriarch Pete is unwilling to pass over control of the kitchen to his son.

HURRICANE KATRINA:

RACE AGAINST TIME

Docuseries | 4 Stars Rating

Streaming from Monday, Disney+

Ahead of the 20th anniversary of the devastating natural disaster, this gripping five-part National Geographic documentary makes one feel right alongside the abject terror with archival footage and the voices of survivors themselves. It's skilfully shown how human decisions and errors compounded the event into becoming a

man-made tragedy that truly struck the city and residents of New Orleans, with one interviewee calling it "a hurricane of governmental failure".

MARC MARON: PANICKED

Comedy special | 4 Stars Rating

Streaming from Saturday, HBO Max

With Stephen Colbert's recent axing from his late-night show seat, many suspecting for politically motivated reasons, it feels more important than ever for comedians to keep speaking out. Maron's latest stand-up special opens with a blistering and riotously funny spray against Trump, or as he describes him, "this sociopathic huckster clown king", his supporters and policies. The 70-minute set also delves into Maron's intrusive catastrophic thinking and the cognitive decline of his father, both of which he makes sound much funnier than one would believe possible.

urn:contentItem:6FYS-DCB3-RS2M-X4CM-00000-00June 03, 2025: Tulane University: Nearly 20 years later, New Orleans post-Katrina school reforms show gains - but at a cost2025-06-05T00:00:00Z2025-08-20T19:20:52ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSJune 03, 2025: Tulane University: Nearly 20 years later, New Orleans post-Katrina school reforms show gains - but at a cost

In the wake of Hurricane Katrina, one of the worst disasters in U.S. history, New Orleans launched the most ambitious school reform experiment in the nation. Almost 20 years later, a new report offers a complex portrait of progress and trade-offs that education policymakers throughout the country are still scrutinizing.

The report by Tulane University's Education Research Alliance for New Orleans summarizes more than a decade of research into 12 key lessons from the city's sweeping education reforms. Those changes were driven largely by the flooding and destruction of many school buildings and a history of underperformance by schools within the traditional system. In the wake of Katrina, the state of Louisiana took over most of the city's schools, resulting in a system where nearly all public schools became charter schools.

The report found that student outcomes improved dramatically following the near-total overhaul of the city's public school system under the new post-Katrina system. Test scores, high school graduation rates and college attendance all rose - sometimes by double digits - after the city shifted almost all public schools to independently operated charter schools governed by performance contracts.

urn:contentItem:6G21-WGW3-S1MF-D347-00000-00tubi Stone stands up for sisterhood2025-06-15T00:00:00Z2025-08-20T19:20:52ZLexisNexisTVPg. 5tubi Stone stands up for sisterhood

NEVER afraid to speak her mind or seek fair compensation for her work, Sharon Stone (pictured) was long labelled a diva. However, as some of Hollywood's uglier truths have been exposed in recent years, audiences have come to view the 67-year-old more sympathetically.

In the insightful Tubi documentary Sharon Stone: Survival Instinct, the Oscar nominee says of her 30-year career: "I feel like my biggest achievement is surviving, because it's a big deal to survive in a business such as this." Stone recently made headlines again when a 2023 interview with industry website Deadline resurfaced, in which she highlighted Hollywood's pay gap.

"When I did Basic Instinct, Michael Douglas made $14 million and I made $500,000," Stone said. "Last year, there was a $100 million film being made by a studio, and the actor, who was new, was going to be paid something like $8 million or $9 millionâ€¦ and the studio offered me again $500,000 to be the female leadâ€¦ So, I don't think it has changed much." You can appreciate Stone's ability to defy expectations in the following films: Sharon Stone: Survival Instinct: This doco explores how Stone became Hollywood's modern-day bombshell.

The Quick And The Dead: Stone joins gun-slinging heavyweights Russell Crowe, Gene Hackman and Leonardo DiCaprio in this underappreciated western directed by Sam Raimi.

Streets Of Blood: Set in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina in 2005, this 2009 film sees Stone play a therapist trying to help shattered police detectives deal with their struggles amid the disaster.

urn:contentItem:6GGK-NJW3-RSB5-04PJ-00000-00Tracking app Life360's shares jump on revenue, succession2025-08-13T00:00:00Z2025-08-20T19:20:52ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 15Tracking app Life360's shares jump on revenue, successionJOSEPH CARBONE

New Life360 chief executive Lauren Antonoff says the family tracking app business and its fast growth have all the hallmarks of companies that went on to rule Silicon Valley.

She described the service as "medicine for the soul" in an age of heightened anxiety.

Ms Antonoff was promoted from chief operating officer to founder Chris Hulls's successor on Tuesday. Mr Hulls will become Life360's executive chairman, having led the company for almost two decades.

"I really feel like we're just getting started," Ms Antonoff told The Australian from San Francisco. "We're still building that base of users.

"Life360 is an incredibly important mission. As a mum, I know how important that peace of mind is, and so to lead a company with a compelling mission and a great business is the opportunity of a lifetime.

"I like to tell my friends that I didn't come to a smaller company. I came to a big company that's just earlier in its journey." Life360 logged 88 million monthly active users, a 25 per cent rise year on year, reporting its second-quarter results on Tuesday. The company added 136,000 new paying customers, to 2.5 million.

Quarterly revenue jumped 36 per cent year on year to $US115.4m ($176.9m) as annualised revenue rose 36 per cent, to $US416.1m. The $6.5bn company also lifted full-year guidance, forecasting revenue of between $US462m and $US482m (up from between $US450m and $US480m) and adjusted EBITDA of between $US72m and $US82m (up from between $US65m and $US75m).

Local shares of the Nasdaq- and ASX-listed company were up 8.9 per cent to $41.20.

Citi analysts, led by Siraj Ahmed, were positive on the result, affirming a "buy" rating and a $90 target price. User growth and a 35 per cent rise in annual revenue per paying customer were reasons for optimism, the broker said. Citi expects another profit beat, given it tends to do better in the second half, making its guidance appear conservative.

Founded by Mr Hulls as a service that could help families locate each other in the wake of Hurricane Katrina, Life360's continued success in the "anxiety economy" and at a time of budgetary constraint showed how important the service was to its customers, Ms Antonoff said.

"There are things that people give up first and that people give up last, and we are proving to be in the latter category," she said.

"We are not a luxury, we are medicine for the soul." Ms Antonoff, 55, who has worked at Microsoft and GoDaddy, has an 18-year-old son who has just qualified for his driver's licence and a 26-year-old daughter living interstate.

She said she was introduced to tracking devices after the family dog ran away (it was found two days later). "I started to research trackers, and actually said to my husband â€¦ how I should go work on something like that. About a month later, Life360 called." The new pet-specific tracking products and advertising business - where Life360 struck a deal with Uber to ping Life360 customers with Uber ads when at the airport, for example - hopefully would become key pillars of the company one day, she said.

"Brands are interested and hungry for the (ad) product. It's building from the ground up," she said. "I'm excited about the trajectory that we're on and the things that we're doing, whether it be ads on the revenue side or pets on the member side. There's no end in sight to the value that we can create for members and shareholders." Life360 has taken "remote work to the next level" at a time of discussion over proposed work from home laws in Victoria. "After the pandemic, I got to experience how it really could be productive, and I liked it for myself," Ms Antonoff said.

urn:contentItem:6GGF-X8N3-RTKK-84WK-00000-00Tracking app Life360's shares jump on revenue, CEO succession2025-08-12T00:00:00Z2025-08-20T19:20:52ZLexisNexisTracking app Life360's shares jump on revenue, CEO succession

Document links may not lead to an active page. Page maintenance is at the discretion of the publisher.

Joseph Carbone

New Life360 chief executive Lauren Antonoff says the family tracking app business and its fast growth have all the hallmarks of companies that went on to rule Silicon Valley.

She described the service as "medicine for the soul" in an age of heightened anxiety.

Ms Antonoff was promoted from chief operating officer to founder Chris Hulls's successor on Tuesday. Mr Hulls will become Life360's executive chairman, having led the company for almost two decades.

"I really feel like we're just getting started," Ms Antonoff told The Australian from San Francisco. "We're still building that base of users.

"Life360 is an incredibly important mission. As a mum, I know how important that peace of mind is, and so to lead a company with a compelling mission and a great business is the opportunity of a lifetime."

"I like to tell my friends that I didn't come to a smaller company. I came to a big company that's just earlier in its journey."

Life360 logged 88 million monthly active users, a 25 per cent rise year on year, reporting its second-quarter results on Tuesday. The company added 136,000 new paying customers, to 2.5 million.

Quarterly revenue jumped 36 per cent year on year to $US115.4m ($176.9m) as annualised revenue rose 36 per cent, to $US416.1m.

The $6.5bn company also lifted full-year guidance, forecasting revenue of between $US462m and $US482m (up from between $US450m and $US480m) and adjusted EBITDA of between $US72m and $US82m (up from between $US65m and $US75m).

Local shares of the Nasdaq- and ASX-listed company were up 8.9 per cent to $41.20.

Citi analysts, led by Siraj Ahmed, were positive on the result, affirming a "buy" rating and a $90 target price. User growth and a 35 per cent rise in annual revenue per paying customer were reasons for optimism, the broker said.

Citi expects another profit beat, given it tends to do better in the second half, making its guidance appear conservative.

Founded by Mr Hulls as a service that could help families locate each other in the wake of Hurricane Katrina, Ms Antonoff said Life360's continued success in the "anxiety economy" and at a time of budgetary constraint showed how important the service was to its customers.

"There are things that people give up first and that people give up last, and we are proving to be in the latter category," she said.

"We are not a luxury, we are medicine for the soul."

Ms Antonoff, 55, has an 18-year-old son who has just qualified for his driver's licence and a 26-year-old daughter living interstate.

Ms Antonoff, who has worked at Microsoft and GoDaddy, said she was introduced to tracking devices after the family dog ran away (it was found two days later). "I started to research trackers, and actually said to my husband ... made an offhand comment about how I should go work on something like that. About a month later, Life360 called."

The new pet-specific tracking products and advertising business - where Life360 struck a deal with Uberto ping Life360 customers with Uber ads when at the airport, for example - will hopefully one day become key pillars of the company, she said.

"Brands are interested and hungry for the (ad) product. It's building from the ground up," she said. "I'm excited about the trajectory that we're on and the things that we're doing, whether it be ads on the revenue side or pets on the member side. There's no end in sight to the value that we can create for members and shareholders."

Life360 has taken "remote work to the next level", according to Ms Antonoff, at a time of intense discussion over proposed work from home laws being introduced in Victoria.

"After the pandemic, I got to experience how it really could be productive, and I liked it for myself," Ms Antonoff said.

"I think that the key that a lot of people don't understand is that the thing that makes remote work work so well for us is that we believe in in-person, face-to-face time.

"It's not all about being on Zoom, which is important. But we also invested a lot of expense we used to use on physical real estate to make sure teams can get together and build relationships."

urn:contentItem:6GGX-X823-RRYM-S2H4-00000-00'I think of you (dying)': Parents' anxiety drove Life360 record growth2025-08-19T00:00:00Z2025-08-20T19:20:52ZLexisNexis'I think of you (dying)': Parents' anxiety drove Life360 record growthTess Bennett

The family-tracking app has booked record revenue growth after leaning in to its reputation for serving "helicopter parents" with a viral ad.

Follow our live coverage of the August 2025 ASX reporting season.

The new chief executive of family tracking app Life360 says rising anxiety among parents about their children's safety is driving record revenue growth, as families now view the ability to keep tabs on loved ones' whereabouts similarly to an essential service.

Alongside its half-yearly earnings announcement on Tuesday, the California-based ASX tech stock said co-founder Chris Hulls would step down as chief executive and become executive chairman after nearly two decades, having built a $9.5 billion business billed as the antidote to parents' anxiety over their children's safety.

Youtube link

He will be succeeded by former GoDaddy and Microsoft executive and Life360 chief operating officer ​Lauren ​​Antonoff.

Initially viewed as such a worrying example of a lack of personal privacy in the smartphone era that it was the basis of an episode of dystopian TV series Black Mirror, Life360 recently went viral with an advert that made fun of the helicopter parents who use its app. A Disney-style animated song featured a mother singing to her teenage daughter about all the ways she imagines her dying while she is away from home.

"We're seeing the rise of what we call the anxiety economy - a shift where families are making more values-based decisions and prioritising peace of mind in how they spend," Antonoff said.

"I think of us as the antidote for the anxiety. We're not telling people that there's danger around every corner, but we know that people think about this stuff and the virality of the ad hit a nerve."

Link to Image

The company said Antonoff's ascension was part of a succession plan put in motion when she joined the company two years ago. Hulls cited Life360 research that found 40 per cent of parents consider safety and emergency alert apps had become non-negotiable purchases.

"Today, peace of mind isn't a luxury. It's essential. Families are budgeting for it just like Wi-Fi or electricity. That shift is fuelling durable value-driven growth," Hulls said.

Founded in 2008, Life360 now has more than 88 million users. It is mainly used by parents to track where their children are and how fast they are driving. It also owns Tile, a rival to Apple's AirTags, and is developing gadgets to track pets and the elderly.

Results for the six months to June 30 beat analysts' expectations, sending the stock 8 per cent higher to trade at $41.10.

Revenue climbed to $US219 million ($336.2 million) for the half, up 34 per cent on the same period a year ago, while net income rose to $US11.4 million from a loss of $US20.7 million a year prior.

Last quarter, it added 136,000 new paying users, a record for a three-month period, lifting paid subscribers to 2.5 million.

The company has become a favourite among fund managers - its shares have risen more than 81 per cent this year - and last year it also listed on the Nasdaq. With 3.1 million users across Australia and New Zealand, it has also found itself at the centre of debates around parenting and privacy.

Life360 raised its full-year guidance. It now expects revenue to be between $US462 million and $US482 million, up from prior guidance of $450 million to $480 million. While adjusted earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation will be between $US72 million and $US82 million, up from $US65 million to $US75 million.

While teenagers can dislike being tracked, a TikTok trend known as "fambushing" has emerged where kids track their parents' location and surprise them.

Passing the baton

Hulls, who came up with the idea for the app while watching footage of separated families following Hurricane Katrina, reassured investors on Tuesday he would still be employed full-time to work on products and strategy.

Asked by RBC analyst Wei-Weng Chen why Antonoff would be a better CEO than him, Hulls offered a candid response.

"I am someone who works in bursts of creativity, but as a public company, you need consistency. I have pretty, pretty severe ADHD. That's a pretty common founder trait, and it takes a lot out of me to be really consistent," he said.

"Lauren enjoys the systems and scaling process that I quite frankly don't really like and am not gifted at. For me, as a very large shareholder with the majority of my net worth in the company, I am very self-interested in this transition."

Hulls owns 3.8 per cent of the company.

Citi analyst Siraj Ahmed told clients the CEO transition did not come as a surprise and was part of "Life360's evolution" as it works towards a long-term goal of hitting 150 million monthly active users and $US1 billion in revenue.

Antonoff said Life 360's viral ad campaign was viewed more than 20 million times and sparked a "cultural conversation".

urn:contentItem:6GCW-4153-RS2J-C1YR-00000-00Updated: July 29, 2025: Ancient Maya population may have topped 16 million, Tulane research shows and other recent news2025-07-31T00:00:00Z2025-08-20T19:20:53ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSUpdated: July 29, 2025: Ancient Maya population may have topped 16 million, Tulane research shows and other recent news

New research led by Tulane University archaeologists reveals that the ancient Maya civilization was far more populous than previously thought - supporting as many as 16 million people across parts of modern-day Guatemala, southern Mexico and western Belize.

INDEX

SECTION 1 PRESS RELEASES: 2025

SECTION 2 OTHER NEWS: 2025

SECTION 1 PRESS RELEASES: 2025

July 24: Is the nose key to preventing pneumonia? Tulane awarded $7.5 million grant to investigate

Tulane University has been awarded a seven-year, $7.5 million grant from the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute to study how boosting immune cells in the nose could lead to stronger, longer-lasting protection against pneumonia - the world's leading infectious killer of children.

Source: Company Website

June 02: Tulane University: Tulane's Tony Hu awarded one of nation's highest honors in clinical diagnostics

The Academy of Diagnostics and Laboratory Medicine (ADLM) has awarded Tulane University research scientist Tony Hu, PhD, the 2025 Academy Award for Outstanding Contributions to Clinical Chemistry in a Selected Area of Research.

One of the nation's highest honors in clinical diagnostics, the award recognizes clinical chemists whose pioneering research efforts have placed them among the world's foremost experts in their fields. ADLM is a global scientific and medical professional organization dedicated to clinical laboratory science and its application to healthcare.

Hu, the Weatherhead Presidential Chair in Biotechnology Innovation at Tulane, leads the Center for Cellular & Molecular Diagnostics at Tulane University School of Medicine where he and his lab have developed revolutionary advancements in disease diagnostics. This includes blood-based and portable tuberculosis diagnostic tools, which can boost TB testing access and accuracy for children, as well as CRISPR-based tools that can detect infectious diseases sooner than conventional methods.

Source: Company Website

July 18: Tulane University: An FDA-backed metric used to determine effectiveness of rectal cancer drugs may be unreliable, says new study

A new study by a Tulane University researcher casts doubt on a widely used shortcut in rectal cancer drug trials, raising concerns that some treatments may be fast-tracked for approval without evidence they help patients live longer.

Source: Company Website

July 08: Tulane University: New drug targets 'zombie cells' in effort to prevent liver disease, cancer

A new drug candidate developed by Tulane University researchers may work to prevent a common type of fatty liver disease. The disease, metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD), sometimes leads to cirrhosis and liver cancer.

Source: Company Website

June 27: Tulane University: Beetle-inspired TB test could close the diagnostic gap in HIV hotspots

Current tuberculosis infection tests struggle to detect the disease in those with HIV. A common co-infection, HIV can hide TB from traditional tests by eliminating the immune cells relied upon to sound the alarm.

Source: Company Website

June 26: Growing Up: Family Day expands to Sunday at New Orleans Book Festival at Tulane University

The New Orleans Book Festival at Tulane University is growing-and so is the magic for families. Festival organizers have announced that in 2026, the beloved Family Day at the Fest will move to Sunday, March 15, creating a dedicated day of literary fun just for children and families to wrap up the weekend. The book festival also announced that author submissions for the 2026 event are now open.

Amelia Manning, former chief operating officer at Southern New Hampshire University (SNHU), has been named dean of Tulane University's School of Professional Advancement (SoPA), effective Aug. 1.

Manning brings more than two decades of leadership experience in higher education, including an extensive track record of innovation and student-focused growth.
